"@akanygren @firefox using the A entries early is an optimization as soon as possible. Using the AAAA entries early simply fails too often to be practical. That's why the pref defaults like that."
"@akanygren @firefox the thing is we don't yet have a global "ipv6 connectivity works" in Firefox - once that comes, we can do early AAAA for those with working ipv6..."
"@akanygren @firefox so many systems have local IPv6, but not working IPv6 connectivity..."
"@akanygren @firefox for non-mac, that's basically the same, but early AAAA from DoH risk to fail the connect before any A entries arrive. that doesn't happen for native resolve"
"@akanygren @firefox right, this is certainly not ideal, but a stop-gap optimization (for time-to-connect) until we can do it better..."
"@akanygren @firefox right, this is certainly not ideal, but a stop-gap optimization (for time-to-connect) until we can do it better..."
"@akanygren @firefox if you set the early-AAAA pref to true, that's basically what it does. And it then adds the other entries as they arrive."
"@akanygren @firefox yes, that could certainly be done -. its just code. You know, its just a matter of in which order to do all those things..."

"Unless I'm misreading, the default false behavior for @FireFox's 
network.trr.early-AAAA setting for TRR/DoH seems the opposite direction from where most browsers have been trying to improve their #IPv6 Happy Eyeballs behavior. Measuring just DNS time is misleading. (CC: @bagder)"

"@bagder @firefox This is surprising.  Clearly with a AAAA NODATA you can't use it early, but if a client has IPv6 connectivity and gets a AAAA response back then using that before using an A record is what many other clients do successfully.  RFC8305 has general guidance here."

"@bagder @firefox This is surprising.  Clearly with a AAAA NODATA you can't use it early, but if a client has IPv6 connectivity and gets a AAAA response back then using that before using an A record is what many other clients do successfully.  RFC8305 has general guidance here."

"@bagder @firefox Are there reasons why you'd get a AAAA back from DoH but not the system resolver? In the system resolver case the usual behavior is to use the AAAA response and to fall back to IPv4 only if IPv6 doesn't connect within a reasonable time."

"@bagder @firefox With more and more networks running IPv4-as-a-Service over IPv6, or breaking out IPv6 locally and sending IPv4 via a CGNAT, the overall perf can be worse by defaulting to IPv4 and will cause performance/scale issues for networks relying on clients preferring to use IPv6."

"@bagder @firefox Is it an option to kick off the TCP SYNs at the times we get the responses?  ie, the IPv4 SYN when the A comes back and the IPv6 SYN when the AAAA comes back?  If the IPv6/AAAA connection establishes first you use it.  If the IPv4/A conn establishes first, use a timing param."

"@bagder @firefox I also wonder if you can use whether the DoH/TRR service is connected to over IPv6 as a cheap IPv6 connectivity check?  eg, if that connection is IPv6, default network.trr.early-AAAA on?"

"@bagder @firefox Hah, yes.  "Just a matter of code."  (In its current experimental realm it's likely a much lower priority, but becomes considerably more important when leaving experimental/nightly. I'd rather not see Unhappy Eyeballs backslides or people hacking in delays on "A" responses.)"

"@mcmanusducksong @bagder @firefox Do you do rfc7050 nat64 synthesis already when using DoH/TRR, or have plans to, in OSes not doing it in the OS (ie, iOS)?  Many large mobile networks are 90%+ IPv6 (with some as dual-stack, others as DNS64+NAT64)."

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox Is it a bug?

* Means match 0 or as many versions of it as possible.

/g means find all matches

It matches the entire string. Then it searches again at the end for further occurrences - finds no characters which is a match.

Without /g it stops after the first match."

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox The interesting thing is that it only does one further match.

* Is really greedy. As such it'll eat empty strings.

Once you've sliced the entire string out of the string, you're left with an empty string, which matches. Technically that could go on forever..."

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox No problem. In production .* Is very greedy and you'd try to avoid it and define your pattern better.

As such if you were to look for everything youd probably use /^.*$/ to tell it to go from beginning to end. I'd imagine that would only return one string."

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox To follow up that explanation, is it certain it's reached the end of the string? It's gone through and found as many "any" chars as possible. Stops, makes its collected string then looks again.

Telling it with $ to continue til it reaches the end tells it it's reached the end."

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox I'd assume it stops after the second string as it checks what it's found against what's left and finds then to be equal. Or some similar reasoning"

"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox Ooh, that's interesting. Based on my initial reasoning it didn't know it's reached the end.

However, from your tests, it's more likely it doesn't know it started from the beginning."
"@BenJ_Ayc0 @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox Precisely :-)"

"Can someone explain me this in JS:
> "this is a random string".replace(/.*/g, "x")
'xx'
Should it be 'x' ?

This behavior is stable among @nodejs , IE, @googlechrome  and @firefox"
"@DeveloperStuart @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox But there is only one match possible: the whole string"

"@DeveloperStuart @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox As the end of the string is already reached once, shouldn't the algorithm immediately stop?

This might not be a bug because according to https://t.co/04NWKXOZfS, python, go and php behave the same way (but not sed)"
"@DeveloperStuart @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox Thanks for the explanation üëç"

"@DeveloperStuart @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox It does:
/.*/
/.+/
/.+/g
/^.*/
/^.*/g
/^.*$/
/^.*$/g

all of them match the entire string once"

"@DeveloperStuart @javascriptd @nodejs @googlechrome @firefox and "string".replace(/.*$/g, 'a') returns 'aa'

Because as you said "Once you've sliced the entire string out of the string, you're left with an empty string" and this empty string matches .*$"

Now, if you could tell a browser to only trust a root cert chain for hosts on the LAN & offer helpful prompts for that..."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox *I* can. Your typical end user *can't*. This whole system is tailored towards people that know what they are doing. There are end-users all around the globe now running their own LANs who sometimes don't even know what an IP is. A large part of the user base gets lost here."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Custom CAs and adding new trusted root certs isn't the answer here. Not if the workflows and messages stay as they are now.

A significant percentage of the user base don't understand this stuff, don't understand why they should understand it and are utterly lost."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox The consequence is either that they cause ridiculous overhead for people providing support for affected software (read: people like me, and I barely have enough time to maintain this project as is). Or they just learn to ignore and find their way around warnings."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Even if they shouldn't. Case in point: People happily opening up port forwards in their routers to internal IOT devices since this is the only way they know how to access their devices from remote."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Also please tell me how *limiting* the trust "radius" of an installed root cert to a subset of domains or target systems would pose a security risk compared to having people install root certs trusted for *all* hosts."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox I'm using/want to use https in a local network because browser vendors are more and more pushing to have their browser mark anything that isn't HTTPS as unsafe and scare users. And because people keep opening ports on their routers (which they Google without understanding)."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox And yes, they can Google that stuff for CAs but first they get a ridiculously scary message (try opening self signed in Chrome) and then they might do this also for hosts on the internet to make the message go away (since it worked once, right?)."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox My whole point here is the status quo is too undecipherable for a large percentage of people and either they get scared or - maybe worse - they work around the warnings and open themselves up for actual attacks.

There are solutions but they ignore reality for a lot of people."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox "I just installed OctoPrint but now my browser is telling me the connection is unsafe!?"

"What is this certificate stuff, I just want to print, and why is my browser saying my password is being stolen?"

"So I clicked on the internet and my OctoPi said it's insecure?""
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Except we aren't talking about employees here but a out retired grandpas with 3d printers for their model building."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Which one was that again? Routers acting as CAs? http redirecting to https only after cert installation? Both still have huge usability issues and teach things to users that better stay untaught in most cases for risk of foot shooting."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Ah, I missed that one.

I don't want to force people into the cloud just to be able to access their instances without being scared by their browser.

Some people also don't want cloud anything.

I don't have time for administrating this.

And there's always the GDPR too."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox If the only real answer to accessing devices on your LAN without the browser screaming bloody murder is to access them through a public cloud service then technology has failed hard."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox I guess it's time then soon for open source projects like OctoPrint, ownCloud and other self hosted appliances to pack up and leave the field to corporations to offer solutions without warnings but a ton of tracking.

Ah well."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Part of working within that environment is also speaking up when I see a huge problem arising.

And you misunderstand. I'm not blaming Google. I'm just saying that the current hard approach with no yielding for the LAN might have consequences."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox It certainly would be nice to see solutions from the community, but huge parts don't even acknowledge that there is a problem and has been growing for years now, which was the whole point of the original thread.

So I don't see that happening when there's still time."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox As I wrote in the original thread, a solution for this is tricky. But I don't think that categorically treating the LAN the same as the internet is the answer.

Even bringing the "trust this page" button back on LAN hosts would go a long way already."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox As would a less scary untrusted cert page *on the LAN*.

It shouldn't make it sound like the host is trying to kill your dog if I need to connect to a new device I own on my LAN via self signed https for the first time."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text: "@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox And I know you said "the browsers won't change" - but honestly, they already have a lot, and I don't see why *the community* can't raise their voices here a bit to make some things a tad bit better maybe."
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

text:
"@B3DMax @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox It's there after you click on the small advanced options (at least in Chrome). I once had a 30min phone call with a relative trying to connect to a new router revolving around this nicely hidden feature.

I know why it was hidden. It makes sense on the net. It's disputable on LAN"
tags: EN,Fan Luv,Help Me,No Action Taken,Cert Issues

"I know this is going to be ignored but @Firefox should also kill that annoying popup that nags me to update nightly. I know I‚Äôm supposed to keep it up to date all the time but that popup is stupid because it ignores people who update it themselves with a cron job"

".@Firefox seems to be toying with asking for permission to ‚Äúautoplay media with sound‚Äù (no idea how they arrive at that categorization). I‚Äôve so far just seen it twice but
(1) it doesn‚Äôt work, and
(2) it‚Äôs extremely annoying and looks like will break tons of sites.
Kill it please"

"@little_potato Hi, this feature is currently only active on Nightly and will land early October in the main release branch. Most sites aren't affected as far as I can see(I'm testing this). You're free to use the "Remember this decision" checkbox to make your decision permanent. -JH"
"@little_potato Also, you are able to disable this feature in your Privacy settings. -JH"

"@firefox Thanks for the note. I still feel this is a huge usability issue because first of all, how does Firefox define autoplay? This is not explained. For example, one of my timer tasks can be configured to play a sound every second."

"@firefox The way Firefox restores sessions may cause this behaviour to be restored when it restores the tab, but it ultimately was caused by previous user action. This isn‚Äôt currently affected but I also feel very insecure as a site designer about audio in Firefox."

"@firefox Also, what are the implications for accessibility? I can see how Firefox is doing this to comply with the WCAG but what about designs that use audio for accessibility purposes? This ‚Äúfeature‚Äù basically kills that design option."

"@firefox Thanks for the note. I‚Äôm glad this is being tested out on nightly first and I hope you guys take our comments seriously. The usability is not working. Privacy settings is the first thing I thought but I never even saw that setting because bug 1410302 is officially wontfix."

"@firefox The devs need to be aware that mobile, mouse (scroll bar), and screen reader (tabbing) are not the only possibilities. Even if you‚Äôre only considering OS-supported accessibility features mouse key users seem to be currently completely left out and ignored."

"@firefox Once I figure out how to get the screen reader working on Ubuntu I‚Äôm going to see how this works out there too; my gut feeling is this isn‚Äôt going to work very well for screen reader users either but obviously I‚Äôd like to be proved wrong on this point."

"@little_potato Hi, thanks for your thoughts. We really take these comments seriously. Autoplay is defined as the media starts playing without the user did an explicit click(or touch) on something. So, for example, if you click the Play-Button on a site, it isn't autoplay and passed on. -JH"

"@little_potato I can confirm that this privacy setting exists on my Nightly installation. I'm asked Mozilla staff and I'm waiting, but I'll come back to you with what implications this has. Accessibility is very important for Mozilla, because we are fighting for a *really* free internet. -JH"
"@little_potato In case you found out that something doesn't worked, please feel free to report this flaw, so disabled users can have a better experience: https://t.co/CVMktTnpmZ -JH"

"@little_potato I can confirm that this privacy setting exists in my installation. I asked Mozilla staff and I'm waiting for a reply, but I'll come back to you with what implications this has. A11y is very important for Mozilla, because we are fighting for a *really* free internet. -JH -JH"

"@firefox Yes, you are correct and I‚Äôve now found it. The problem is with PgUp/PgDn non-working by default and scrollbars being difficult to use for mousekey users, I (and if I‚Äôm allowed to generalize, we) open up preferences, see that we can‚Äôt scroll, and close preferences without looking"
"@firefox Thanks for the explanation but I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs more to it because my two timer tasks are not (yet) affected. This is going to be a big problem for artists working with audio..."

"@jens1o @firefox https://t.co/MynPl74oKv has been mentioned in my blog.
The other one isn‚Äôt really ready"

"@jens1o @firefox That‚Äôs precisely the problem. If autoplay is defined as some audio being played without the user initiating a click first, my clock page should not work.

So for designers trying to incorporate audio in their sites Firefox is now an unpredictable unknown"
"@jens1o @firefox ‚ÄúVery unpredictable‚Äù can‚Äôt possibly be good for marketing"

"@jens1o @firefox If my clock page(s, since there‚Äôs also the not-so-ready one) stopped working I would be really unhappy, but at least Firefox is being consistent. Right now it‚Äôs not consistent at all. From a user‚Äôs POV it‚Äôs ‚Äúsometimes audio works, sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, but I can‚Äôt see a pattern‚Äù"

"@little_potato A case study will follow soon, asking users for feedback when they expected something to be block or not(https://t.co/doCnUhck8k). Also, we want to log a message when we detect something the user would not like a specific media to be played(https://t.co/xltyl2pKH9) (1/2) -JH"
"@little_potato to help site developers to improve their site to how a user would expect something. (2/2) -JH"

"@firefox From my personal POV the main culprits are news sites. Even sites in Ontario (where this kind of autoplaying is technically illegal) they autoplay videos with voice. This is a huge issue but I can‚Äôt see how the current blocking mechanism works without some tweaks."

"@jens1o @firefox I‚Äôm personally very wary of AI. Even spam detection, supposedly a well studied area, is fraught with problems. I hope more non-English-speaking researchers/designers are contributing to this kind of AI or we‚Äôre get some very biased solutions"

"@jens1o @firefox BTW, just to be perfectly clear, I‚Äôm not in the target community when it comes to accessibility. I‚Äôm just a recent grad from a program that talks about such things; on the personal experience side I can only say I use an Acer (touchpad doesn‚Äôt really work so I rely on mousekeys)"
"@little_potato Mozilla is open for peaceful discussions. No worries. :) I'm still waiting for an response of a11y-focused employees (-> timezones). -JH"

"@firefox I just saw a comment on a bug I just reported (related to this issue but not this issue). With the kind of dismissing attitude I‚Äôve been seeing it‚Äôs very difficult to remain peaceful.

It‚Äôs hard to actually file any reports at all any more. All I can feel is users are not valued."
"@firefox And beware of what you write on Bugzilla, because people with admin privs do tamper with the evidence. It happened last time I filed a report."

"@little_potato Hi, this shouldn't be true. I couldn't find exact examples of what you are describing in the last two days, but please report this behavior to inclusion@mozilla.com, because such behavior is absolutely unacceptable. The Mozilla Community has rules: https://t.co/6zxv6elM8J -JH"

"@little_potato The community is very, very important for us. That's an example, why we are here to support people, because we do value them. Diversity and Inclusion for everyone is a very serious concern of us. -JH"

"@Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox You don't. What I'd like to see happen is have router manufacturers offer CA's for local signing. You can install the root from the router and then request it for your internal servers."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Browsers will never do that. It opens up a critical security attack vector. And would leave it far too open to spoofing. In Chrome and Firefox you can easily trust and accept a self-signed certificate and it won't prompt you again. A few minutes of Education fixes the "problem""

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Nobody is saying install a root cert for all hosts. And I think clicking advanced and proceed to site, two clicks, is doable. The question is why are you using ssl inside a home network? If people are able to open a port in their router to allow access, they can accept a cert."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Maybe a better idea is spinning up a paid service for $5 or $10 a month to facilitate secure access to their octoprint instance."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox So let's facilitate a good, safe, simple solution for them and possibly make a few bucks for further octoprint devopment."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Shouldn't be too hard to set something up."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox So start the connection with http, then tell them what they need to do to accept the cert, then switch over to https."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Working for large companies with the whole range of companies, I've dealt with the lowest technical people in an it scenario. You just have to outsmart them."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Same level of technological experience. I mentioned a great solution that can bring a few dollars in too. That's the optimal solution."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Create a service that allows octoprint to connect to it. The users connect to the secure gateway and get tunneled back to octoprint. The same way Plex Media Server does it, and most remote assistance applications. It's quick and easy and can be a subscription service."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox No ports open in their router. No scarry ssl warnings."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Then you're wasting your breath. Browsers will not change and i wouldn't want them to. Having a how-to with an explanation is the quickest answer. If people can google, follow direction and open ports. A brief explanation and clicking two buttons won't kill them."
"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Technology hasn't failed. Trust and common sense have. Technology is dealing with these issues. Your personal network can't be trusted anymore."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox So it seems it's time for the community to come up with a solution. Don't throw in the towel and blame corporations who are actually looking out for the security of their users in this case. The ssl redtriction has nothing to do with tracking. I deal with it every day in my job."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox We are more secure because of it. I applaud them for doing it. But it's up to us to work within the changing environment. Security shouldn't be stagnant like it has been for the last 20 years."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Well we partially agree then. But I'm still not convinced yielding to Lan is the way to go. What happens when someone brings a compromised device into your network, now it's trusted."

"@OctoPrint3D @Think3dPrint3d @ChromiumDev @firefox Well we partially agree then. But I'm still not convinced yielding to Lan is the way to go. What happens when someone brings a compromised device into your network, now it's trusted."

"@mlissner @firefox It needs to be able to consume the HTTP requests because that is when it gets access to the HTTP stream. It‚Äôs a WebExtension limitation unfortunately.

If I could do this with less broad permissions, I totally would."
"@mlissner @firefox Technically the browser has access to it before the server has sent any content at all, but there is no general WebExtension event handler for this particular point in time."
"@mlissner @firefox WebExtensions are pretty well sandboxed from each other and from a lot of things. They‚Äôre a lot safer than the previous addons, which had access to basically everything."
"@NightmareJS @firefox You are very welcome! Enjoy and let me know if you run into any bugs!"
"@mlissner @firefox That is already done.  :)"
"@mlissner @firefox As for the bug, probably not. There aren‚Äôt many needs for getting every HTTP request without being able to get any of the headers or content. It‚Äôs basically TLS stuff only."
"@RandomFFUser @firefox I‚Äôm lucky to have such a fan!  :D"
"@ClaasAug @firefox There‚Äôs no reason it couldn‚Äôt be updated to work with this new API, for sure.  :)"

"@MikeConca @firefox Will do! I‚Äôve been filing lots of bugs around this little corner of the WebExtension universe to make it even better.  :)

And I‚Äôm glad you like it! Thanks for helping to make this API happen!"

text: "@robinberjon Um... Yes? For example, @SamsungInternet includes a tracking blocker (@disconnectme), @brave is basically all about privacy, @firefox now bundles tracking blocker & back-ports Tor features, etc... I feel like there is a renaissance of privacy-enabling-tech in browsers right now."

"@robinberjon @samsunginternet @disconnectme @brave @firefox I agree tracking protection should be on by default. In other news, in preparing for this workshop on permissions I was re-reading https://t.co/xbM1V4JjeX."

"@drogersuk @robinberjon @samsunginternet @disconnectme @brave @firefox ...which is exactly why we need to take a new look at user permission and consent. We are in crisis. The current permissions model is broken and rife with abuse. As we add more powerful features to the web we need to fix it."
"@robinberjon @samsunginternet @disconnectme @brave @firefox üé∂ Memories... üé∂"

"@robinberjon @drogersuk @samsunginternet @disconnectme @brave @firefox In all seriousness: when we held that workshop, the issues being discussed were somewhat theoretical. Now they are very real. In light of that reality, it's time to take a new look at user permissions and consent."

"@MustafaAbobakr @firefox Hi! Please keep pressing shift while starting Firefox. It will start in safe mode with fewer chances of crashing. Once you start it, go to about:crashes and copy the last crash id. Please report a bug and include the crash id https://t.co/JZRLbVDRQz #fxhelp"
"@MustafaAbobakr @firefox After you report the bug, try a profile refresh https://t.co/elaSobDwhF #fxhelp"

"@MustafaAbobakr @firefox Modern extensions rarely cause crashes. In theory it should be impossible for them to do it. Safe mode also disables hardware acceleration. Some time people run out of date video drivers that cause crashes. Pleaese report a bug and include the crash id."

"@MustafaAbobakr @firefox If indeed that is the cause of the issue, please report a bug. It looks like a bug in extension API. No addon should be able to crash the browser. Sorry if I sound like a broken record about the bug reporting thing :D"

"@MustafaAbobakr @firefox Well... if it still happens after you removed the addon then it is not an addon/API thing. Please try in a new profile https://t.co/QEn5y6JhWs and report the bug. https://t.co/JZRLbVDRQz #fxhelp"
